newsitem.title: UK: Glaxo wins UK approval for malaria drug.
newsitem.headline: Glaxo wins UK approval for malaria drug.

text.p: Glaxo Wellcome Plc said on Wednesday it has won UK approval for its new Malarone malaria treatment, opening the way for approval in countries where the disease is endemic.
The company said clinical trials of Malarone showed the drug was extremely effective in treating malaria, including drug resistant strains.

Glaxo Wellcome, which presented results of the trials at a conference in Japan on tropical diseases, said Malarone, a combination of atovaquone plus proguanil, achieved a 98.5 percent cure rate in more than 400 patients aged from three to eighty in seven countries.
Glaxo Wellcome is planning to give away supplies of the new drug in recognition that need for treatment is greatest in countries least able to afford it.
Controlled supplies of Malarone will be available free of charge to patients with the greatest need for theraby and who would otherwise not have access to the drug.
A pilot donation programme is planned to start in Kenya in mid-1997 and form the basis for expansion to other areas of Africa as well as south east Asia and South America.
